audio_caption: The clip begins with an excited man saying "Get ready" and "Y'all get ready". A woman responds with enthusiasm, saying, "Yes, you'll get ready". The scene transitions to a woman, presumably a different speaker, inviting listeners to "sit some tea", speaking with a casual and friendly tone. She mentions the tea being "piping hot". There is a sound that resembles either steam or a loud hiss. Then, a female speaker begins a new segment, speaking with an encouraging tone. She directs listeners to her online stores, thanking them for their support, and promising the upcoming video. The clip concludes.

The audio clip begins with a woman speaking in an conversational and somewhat excited tone about Joe Budden and Cyn Santana. She mentions "Love & Hip Hop: New York" and how Budden is rebranding himself as a podcaster and TV personality. She then states that he is too busy for sex with Cyn Santana.

The audio clip features one female speaker who sounds worried and is discussing the baby's mother, implying she is upset and insecure about her appearance and the relationship with her partner. The speaker is expressing the baby's mother's concerns, quoting phrases such as "why is he not into me" and "what's going on."

The audio clip begins with a female speaker explaining the premise of the first episode, mentioning "Sin" trying to set up romantic time at a hotel after a podcast event, and wanting to "get it in" with him. She speaks in a casual, conversational tone.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker discussing someone who "just wanted to go home" and is "not into sex." An upbeat, electronic music track begins playing in the background. Another female voice says, excitedly, that a dry spell "is gonna end tonight" and references a "perfect plan in place," adding she "can't wait." A male voice breaks in stating he wants to do "that at home," to which the female voice responds, "I want to go home." The first woman argues that if they don't go to a hotel room, he'll fall asleep and she'll get nothing. There is a sound of traffic, and then a male voice asks "not a good ride?" A woman says "we're busy" and the other man replies saying "driving the car to get to bike." The woman sounds agitated, then a man says "Let's let him go, thank you." Then, one of the woman says "wonderful!" and questions if the man doesn't like "this" and threatens "I'll get out right here and ask," before exclaiming "she will, the driver, everybody." The audio clip ends with another female voice muttering "Jesus, Mary and Joseph."

The clip begins with a male voice speaking, referencing having a job and a baby, and admits to not "getting it on" like they used to. He considers his partner "a little immature about the situation." A soft, slightly melancholic musical score with a piano melody plays in the background alongside his speech.

The clip starts with a female speaker expressing frustration about having to "beg my man for some sex" and how that makes her feel after giving birth. She wants to feel like a woman again. There's an initial male speaker who tries to respond, but she interrupts him. The male speaker states the "hotel is not the problem. The timing..." The female speaker continues to get angry, cutting him off. She's sarcastically says she needs to listen to what he has to say. The female speaker ends the clip by calling him a senior citizen. A hip hop instrumental track plays under the dialogue and adds to the scene.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker discussing a radio show where, according to one of the hosts, he hasn't had sex in a while. Then she talks about a certain Joe Button, quoting that he would be okay if he never had sex again with a certain Sin Santana. A different male speaker interjects, claiming he hasn't had sex in months and hasn't thought about it. Then there is a brief musical sound effect, followed by another male speaker inquiring why the former doesn't want to have sex. This leads to another quick musical sound effect and a back and forth of short humorous comments between two male speakers. A third male speaker states that he'd be okay if he never had sex again. A female speaker replies in a concerned tone, calling it terrible. One of the male speakers asks if they can talk to Sin, and then another says that his fellow speaker doesn't have the luxury of dating a young woman. The third male speaker says he doesn't know, and that he is trying to ride his "toddler thing." The female speaker interjects again, claiming that it's not fair to Sin, to which the male speaker says "Oh my god". Another male speaker then says that's not fair, and she wants to be desirable. The discussion continues about sexual desire, with another male speaker humorously suggesting to "eat it and put it to sleep,". The female speaker reacts strongly with the question about how she feels. The third male speaker then expresses his irritation at women bringing up their feelings.

The audio clip starts with a woman saying "Um, yeah, I mean" in a casual tone. Then, a man with a slightly raspy voice notes that "these mumble rappers is plotting on sin right now," advising someone named Joe that the rappers are aware he is not sleeping with her. Another man responds, commenting they are "DM-ing her" and "giving her problems probably," but assures that he and his "baby" will be alright. The first man is then heard again as he adds, "don't just paint me as the gay guy," causing a stir of confusion among the other speakers as one asks, "The gay guy?" The first man clarifies, "incompetent or whatever." A woman suggests "erectile dysfunction," to which the first man responds, "impotent," clarifying its meaning. Another man then asks if he needs a pill, prompting the first man to respond that while he does not need a pill, they're fun sometimes. This leads the second man to question if his hard drug use has caught up with him at 38, resulting in his inability to "get hard." Amidst the discussion, the first man mentions, "Why go to a hotel when we got a house?" Another man points out that all he's going to do is fall asleep. A woman then complains about having to check into a hotel late at night. The second man states, "We pay a lot of money for a beautiful home. We should be there." The second man states that "Joe" is going to go "wake up Sin" right now, as they need to "have Sin."

The clip starts with a man speaking. He references someone named "Sex" and expresses gratitude for a "great relationship." His tone is conversational and friendly. Next, a woman speaks, beginning with an elongated "Honey" followed by direct address to an audience. She analyzes the relationship dynamics between "Joe Button" and "Sin." She speaks emphatically, advising Sin that she is in danger. She expresses concern that "baby mama syndrome" has kicked in, suggesting Joe obtained what he wanted from Sin, and that Joe is no longer as interested. The woman's analysis continues, highlighting the importance of making time for each other in relationships. In the background, there is a brief sound of what seems to be a slap, or other brief impact sound. The clip closes with music playing a slow R&B song.

The audio clip features a single female speaker discussing the role of sex in relationships. She explains that "relationships are not just about sex," but it's an important factor, and dissatisfaction can lead to partners "looking elsewhere." She then critiques a woman she saw on "Love & Hip Hop," describing her as "very immature" and "annoying." The speaker suggests this woman should let nature take its course, and if her partner doesn't regain sexual interest, she should move on. Her tone is assertive and analytical.

The clip begins with a woman speaking in a concerned tone, questioning what her partner's actions mean, specifically mentioning the weight she has gained since having a baby and his lack of physical affection. She asserts that no one should rush to "snap themselves back" and that her partner's comments on "The Breakfast Club" are unhelpful, suggesting possible underlying issues with him. In an exasperated tone, she alleges he is being "a greedy son of a b," highlighting the change in their dynamic and her over-investment in his life.

The audio clip features a single, articulate female speaker discussing a woman named "Sin" who she feels needs to find her own path, because she only jumps from reality show to reality show. The speaker contrasts "Sin" with "Joe", who is busy and successful. She believes the changing dynamics are causing conflict in the relationship. She concludes that "Sin" should find something outside of "Joe" to focus on and respect his work.

A woman speaks in an energetic tone, commenting on a relationship and perceived issues like idle time, lack of desire, potential infidelity, and the effect of reality television on relationships, stating that "reality television relationships do not last," and predicting a breakup. She suggests both parties need to grow and compromise. She then encourages viewers to leave comments on the "crazy situation". A child's enthusiastic yell is then briefly heard. Following this, a woman speaks in a friendly tone promoting her video, encouraging viewers to click on the description box for more information and to stay tuned for the next video. Upbeat music plays throughout the last woman's speech, featuring a pop-style beat and electronic elements.
